<h2 id="display-objects-as-strings">Display Objects as Strings</h2>
<p>These functions will return an object as a string that shows each of the object's member variables.  They're nice to use if you want to print any Python object, not just PySimpleGUI ones.</p>
<p>Dumps an Object's values as a formatted string.  Very nicely done. Great way to display an object's member variables in human form</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">obj_to_string</span>(obj, extra = <span class="hljs-string">"    "</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>obj</td>
<td>The object to display</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>extra</td>
<td>extra stuff (Default value = ' ')</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Formatted output of the object's values</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Dumps an Object's values as a formatted string.  Very nicely done. Great way to display an object's member variables in human form
Returns only the top-most object's variables instead of drilling down to dispolay more</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">obj_to_string_single_obj</span>(obj)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>obj</td>
<td>The object to display</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Formatted output of the object's values</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2 id="the-main-pysimplegui-program-test-harness-global-settings-debug-information-upgrade-from-github">The Main PySimpleGUI Program - Test Harness, Global Settings, Debug Information, Upgrade from GitHub</h2>
<p>A convention that PySimpleGUI uses is that standalone entry points start with "main_".  These calls are essentially a mini-program within the PySimpleGUI.py file.</p>
<p>Used to get SDK help, test the installation, get information about the versions, upgrade from GitHub.</p>
<p>You can call main() from your code and then access these other features such as the global settings. You can also directly call these functions.</p>
<p>You can also type <code>psgmain</code> from the command line to access it if you have pip installed your copy of PySimpleGUI.</p>
<p>The PySimpleGUI "Test Harness".  This is meant to be a super-quick test of the Elements.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">main</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Collect up and display the data needed to file GitHub issues.
This function will place the information on the clipboard.
You MUST paste the information from the clipboard prior to existing your application (except on Windows).</p>
<pre><code class="hljs yaml"><span class="hljs-string">main_get_debug_data(suppress_popup</span> <span class="hljs-string">=</span> <span class="hljs-literal">False</span><span class="hljs-string">)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_popup</td>
<td>If True no popup window will be shown. The string will be only returned, not displayed</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Window to set settings that will be used across all PySimpleGUI programs that choose to use them.
Use set_options to set the path to the folder for all PySimpleGUI settings.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">main_global_pysimplegui_settings</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if settings were changed</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Display a window that will display the docstrings for each PySimpleGUI Element and the Window object</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">main_sdk_help</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>The PySimpleGUI "Test Harness".  This is meant to be a super-quick test of the Elements.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs bash"><span class="hljs-built_in">test</span>()
</code></pre>
<h2 id="debugger">Debugger</h2>

<h2 id="themes">Themes</h2>
<p>The way to get Windows that have elements that have matching colors.</p>
<p>Sets / Gets the current Theme.  If none is specified then returns the current theme.
This call replaces the ChangeLookAndFeel / change_look_and_feel call which only sets the theme.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">theme</span>(new_theme = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>new_theme</td>
<td>the new theme name to use</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>the currently selected theme</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Add a new theme to the dictionary of themes</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">theme_add_new</span>(new_theme_name, new_theme_dict)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>new_theme_name</td>
<td>text to display in element</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>dict</td>
<td>new_theme_dict</td>
<td>text to display in element</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Sets/Returns the background color currently in use
Used for Windows and containers (Column, Frame, Tab) and tables</p>

</code></pre>

</tr>
</tbody>

</code></pre>

</table>

function and splits apart the tuple</p>

<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">theme_element_text_color</span>(color = None)
</code></pre>

</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Sets / Gets the global PySimpleGUI Theme.  If none is specified then returns the global theme from user settings.
Note the theme must be a standard, built-in PySimpleGUI theme... not a user-created theme.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">theme_global</span>(new_theme = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>

</tr>

</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<p>Displays a "Quick Reference Window" showing all of the different Look and Feel settings that are available.
They are sorted alphabetically.  The legacy color names are mixed in, but otherwise they are sorted into Dark and Light halves</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">theme_previewer(columns = <span class="hljs-number">12</span>,
    scrollable = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>,
    scroll_area_size = (<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>),
    search_string = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    location = (<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>))
</code></pre>

</tr>

<td>If specified then only themes containing this string will be shown</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>location</td>
<td>Location on the screen to place the window. Defaults to the center like all windows</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

If you hover over a color or right click it you'll also see the hext value.</p>

<hr>
<h2 id="platform-checks">Platform Checks</h2>
<p>These are simple functions you can use that return a boolean  True if sys.platform matches the platform.  Saves you the trouble of importing sys and then looking up the values for sys.platform.</p>
<p>Determines the OS is Linux by using sys.platform</p>
<p>Returns True if Linux</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">running_linux</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if sys.platform indicates running Linux</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Determines the OS is Mac by using sys.platform</p>
<p>Returns True if Mac</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">running_mac</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if sys.platform indicates running Mac</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>A special case for Trinket.  Checks both the OS and the number of environment variables
Currently, Trinket only has ONE environment variable.  This fact is used to figure out if Trinket is being used.</p>
<p>Returns True if "Trinket" (in theory)</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">running_trinket</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if sys.platform indicates Linux and the number of environment variables is 1</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Determines the OS is Windows by using sys.platform</p>
<p>Returns True if Windows</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">running_windows</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if sys.platform indicates running Windows</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<hr>
<h2 id="usersettings-api-class-interface">UserSettings API - Class Interface</h2>
<p>The User Settings API is used to store your settings information from one session to another or from one program to another.  They are stored on disk in either JSON or INI file formats.</p>
<p>In addition to user settings files, there is also a global PySimpleGUI settings file that PySimpleGUI uses to store information about the default Python interpreter you want to use with the Exec APIs, the default theme. You can directly access the global settings through the UserSettings object: <code>pysimplegui_user_settings</code></p>
<p>User Settings</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">UserSettings(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    silent_on_error = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>,
    autosave = <span class="hljs-literal">True</span>,
    use_config_file = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    convert_bools_and_none = <span class="hljs-literal">True</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>silent_on_error</td>
<td>If True errors will not be reported</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>autosave</td>
<td>If True the settings file is saved after every update</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_config_file</td>
<td>If True then the file format will be a config.ini rather than json</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>convert_bools_and_none</td>
<td>If True then "True", "False", "None" will be converted to the Python values True, False, None when using INI files. Default is TRUE</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="delete_entry">delete_entry</h3>
<p>Deletes an individual entry.  If no filename has been specified up to this point,
then a default filename will be used.
After value has been deleted, the settings file is written to disk.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs properties"><span class="hljs-attr">delete_entry(key,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">section</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">silent_on_error</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Setting to be deleted. Can be any valid dictionary key type (i.e. must be hashable)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>silent_on_error</td>
<td>Determines if error should be shown. This parameter overrides the silent on error setting for the object.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="delete_file">delete_file</h3>
<p>Deltes the filename and path for your settings file.  Either paramter can be optional.
If you don't choose a path, one is provided for you that is OS specific
Windows path default = users/name/AppData/Local/PySimpleGUI/settings.
If you don't choose a filename, your application's filename + '.json' will be used
Also sets your current dictionary to a blank one.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">delete_file(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    report_error = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>report_error</td>
<td>Determines if an error should be shown if a delete error happen (i.e. file isn't present)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="delete_section">delete_section</h3>
<p>Deletes a section with the name provided in the section parameter.  Your INI file will be saved afterwards if auto-save enabled (default is ON)</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">delete_section</span>(section)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>section</td>
<td>Name of the section to delete</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="exists">exists</h3>
<p>Check if a particular settings file exists.  Returns True if file exists</p>
<pre><code class="hljs sql"><span class="hljs-keyword">exists</span>(filename <span class="hljs-operator">=</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">None</span>, path <span class="hljs-operator">=</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="get_20">get</h3>
<p>Returns the value of a specified setting.  If the setting is not found in the settings dictionary, then
the user specified default value will be returned.  It no default is specified and nothing is found, then
the "default value" is returned.  This default can be specified in this call, or previously defined
by calling set_default. If nothing specified now or previously, then None is returned as default.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs sql"><span class="hljs-keyword">get</span>(key, <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> <span class="hljs-operator">=</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Key used to lookup the setting in the settings dictionary</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>default</td>
<td>Value to use should the key not be found in the dictionary</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(Any)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Value of specified settings</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="get_dict">get_dict</h3>
<p>Returns the current settings dictionary.  If you've not setup the filename for the
settings, a default one will be used and then read.</p>
<p>Note that you can display the dictionary in text format by printing the object itself.</p>
<p><code>get_dict()</code></p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Dict</td>
<td><strong>return</strong></td>
<td>The current settings dictionary</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="get_filename">get_filename</h3>
<p>Sets the filename and path for your settings file.  Either paramter can be optional.</p>
<p>If you don't choose a path, one is provided for you that is OS specific
Windows path default = users/name/AppData/Local/PySimpleGUI/settings.</p>
<p>If you don't choose a filename, your application's filename + '.json' will be used.</p>
<p>Normally the filename and path are split in the user_settings calls. However for this call they
can be combined so that the filename contains both the path and filename.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">get_filename(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The full pathname of the settings file that has both the path and filename combined.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="load">load</h3>
<p>Specifies the path and filename to use for the settings and reads the contents of the file.
The filename can be a full filename including a path, or the path can be specified separately.
If  no filename is specified, then the caller's filename will be used with the extension ".json"</p>
<pre><code class="hljs lua"><span class="hljs-built_in">load</span>(filename = None, <span class="hljs-built_in">path</span> = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>Filename to load settings from (and save to in the future)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>Path to the file. Defaults to a specific folder depending on the operating system</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(dict)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The settings dictionary (i.e. all settings)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="read_4">read</h3>
<p>Reads settings file and returns the dictionary.
If you have anything changed in an existing settings dictionary, you will lose your changes.</p>
<p><code>read()</code></p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(dict)</td>
<td><strong>return</strong></td>
<td>settings dictionary</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="save">save</h3>
<p>Saves the current settings dictionary.  If a filename or path is specified in the call, then it will override any
previously specitfied filename to create a new settings file.  The settings dictionary is then saved to the newly defined file.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">save(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The fFilename to save to. Can specify a path or just the filename. If no filename specified, then the caller's filename will be used.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The (optional) path to use to save the file.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The full path and filename used to save the settings</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="set">set</h3>
<p>Sets an individual setting to the specified value.  If no filename has been specified up to this point,
then a default filename will be used.
After value has been modified, the settings file is written to disk.
Note that this call is not value for a config file normally. If it is, then the key is assumed to be the
Section key and the value written will be the default value.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs vbnet"><span class="hljs-keyword">set</span>(<span class="hljs-keyword">key</span>, value)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Setting to be saved. Can be any valid dictionary key type</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>value</td>
<td>Value to save as the setting's value. Can be anything</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(Any)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>value that key was set to</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="set_default_value">set_default_value</h3>
<p>Set the value that will be returned if a requested setting is not found</p>
<pre><code class="hljs ruby">set_<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span><span class="hljs-title">ault_value</span><span class="hljs-params">(default)</span></span>
</code></pre>

<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>default</td>
<td>value to be returned if a setting is not found in the settings dictionary</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or None)</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<h2 id="user-settings-api-function-interface">User Settings API - Function Interface</h2>
<p>You have a couple of ways to access User Settings if your information is stored in JSON format.  If you're using the INI format, then you must use the <code>UserSettings</code> object.</p>
<p>These are particularly useful directly in layouts, allowing you to you can easily set default values.</p>
<p>Returns the current settings dictionary.  If you've not setup the filename for the
settings, a default one will be used and then read.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">user_settings</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(dict or str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The current settings dictionary as a dictionary or a nicely formatted string representing it</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Deletes an individual entry.  If no filename has been specified up to this point,
then a default filename will be used.
After value has been deleted, the settings file is written to disk.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">user_settings_delete_entry</span>(key, silent_on_error = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Setting to be saved. Can be any valid dictionary key type (hashable)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>silent_on_error</td>
<td>Determines if an error popup should be shown if an error occurs. Overrides the silent onf effort setting from initialization</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Deltes the filename and path for your settings file.  Either paramter can be optional.
If you don't choose a path, one is provided for you that is OS specific
Windows path default = users/name/AppData/Local/PySimpleGUI/settings.
If you don't choose a filename, your application's filename + '.json' will be used
Also sets your current dictionary to a blank one.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">user_settings_delete_filename(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    report_error = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Determines if a settings file exists.  If so a boolean True is returned.
If either a filename or a path is not included, then the appropriate default
will be used.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">user_settings_file_exists(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>Filename to check</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>Path to the file. Defaults to a specific folder depending on the operating system</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(bool)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if the file exists</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Sets the filename and path for your settings file.  Either paramter can be optional.</p>
<p>If you don't choose a path, one is provided for you that is OS specific
Windows path default = users/name/AppData/Local/PySimpleGUI/settings.</p>
<p>If you don't choose a filename, your application's filename + '.json' will be used.</p>
<p>Normally the filename and path are split in the user_settings calls. However for this call they
can be combined so that the filename contains both the path and filename.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">user_settings_filename(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The name of the file to use. Can be a full path and filename or just filename</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The folder that the settings file will be stored in. Do not include the filename.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The full pathname of the settings file that has both the path and filename combined.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Returns the value of a specified setting.  If the setting is not found in the settings dictionary, then
the user specified default value will be returned.  It no default is specified and nothing is found, then
None is returned.  If the key isn't in the dictionary, then it will be added and the settings file saved.
If no filename has been specified up to this point, then a default filename will be assigned and used.
The settings are SAVED prior to returning.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs sql">user_settings_get_entry(key, <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> <span class="hljs-operator">=</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Key used to lookup the setting in the settings dictionary</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>default</td>
<td>Value to use should the key not be found in the dictionary</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(Any)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Value of specified settings</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Specifies the path and filename to use for the settings and reads the contents of the file.
The filename can be a full filename including a path, or the path can be specified separately.
If  no filename is specified, then the caller's filename will be used with the extension ".json"</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">user_settings_load(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>Filename to load settings from (and save to in the future)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>Path to the file. Defaults to a specific folder depending on the operating system</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(dict)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The settings dictionary (i.e. all settings)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Saves the current settings dictionary.  If a filename or path is specified in the call, then it will override any
previously specitfied filename to create a new settings file.  The settings dictionary is then saved to the newly defined file.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">user_settings_save(filename = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, path = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>filename</td>
<td>The fFilename to save to. Can specify a path or just the filename. If no filename specified, then the caller's filename will be used.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>path</td>
<td>The (optional) path to use to save the file.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The full path and filename used to save the settings</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Sets an individual setting to the specified value.  If no filename has been specified up to this point,
then a default filename will be used.
After value has been modified, the settings file is written to disk.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">user_settings_set_entry</span>(key, value)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>key</td>
<td>Setting to be saved. Can be any valid dictionary key type</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>value</td>
<td>Value to save as the setting's value. Can be anything</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Used to control the display of error messages.  By default, error messages are displayed to stdout.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs yaml"><span class="hljs-string">user_settings_silent_on_error(silent_on_error</span> <span class="hljs-string">=</span> <span class="hljs-literal">False</span><span class="hljs-string">)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>

</code></pre>

<hr>
<h2 id="exec-apis-launching-subprocesses">Exec APIs - Launching Subprocesses</h2>
<p>These API calls are used to launch subprocesses.  You can launch Python files or any type of executable file.  In these calls is where you invoke the editor and file explorer that was specified in the PySimpleGUI Global Settings.</p>
<p>Runs the specified command as a subprocess.
By default the call is non-blocking.
The function will immediately return without waiting for the process to complete running. You can use the returned Popen object to communicate with the subprocess and get the results.
Returns a subprocess Popen object.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs properties"><span class="hljs-attr">execute_command_subprocess(command,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">args</span>=<span class="hljs-string">*&lt;1 or N object&gt;,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">wait</span> = <span class="hljs-string">False,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">cwd</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">pipe_output</span> = <span class="hljs-string">False,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">merge_stderr_with_stdout</span> = <span class="hljs-string">True,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">stdin</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>command</td>
<td>Filename to load settings from (and save to in the future)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Any</td>
<td>*args</td>
<td>Variable number of arguments that are passed to the program being started as command line parms</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>wait</td>
<td>If True then wait for the subprocess to finish</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>cwd</td>
<td>Working directory to use when executing the subprocess</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>pipe_output</td>
<td>If True then output from the subprocess will be piped. You MUST empty the pipe by calling execute_get_results or your subprocess will block until no longer full</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>merge_stderr_with_stdout</td>
<td>If True then output from the subprocess stderr will be merged with stdout. The result is ALL output will be on stdout.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>stdin</td>
<td>Value passed to the Popen call. Defaults to subprocess.DEVNULL so that the pyinstaller created executable work correctly</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Popen object</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Runs the editor that was configured in the global settings and opens the file to a specific line number.
Two global settings keys are used.
'-editor program-' the command line used to startup your editor. It's set
in the global settings window or by directly manipulating the PySimpleGUI settings object
'-editor format string-' a string containing 3 "tokens" that describes the command that is executed
<editor> <file> <line></line></file></editor></p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">execute_editor</span>(file_to_edit, line_number = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>file_to_edit</td>
<td>the full path to the file to edit</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>line_number</td>
<td>optional line number to place the cursor</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen) or None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Popen object</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>The global settings has a setting called -   "-explorer program-"
It defines the program to run when this function is called.
The optional folder paramter specified which path should be opened.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">execute_file_explorer</span>(folder_to_open = <span class="hljs-string">""</span>)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>folder_to_open</td>
<td>The path to open in the explorer program</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen) or None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Popen object</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Returns the first filename found in a traceback that is not the name of this file (<strong>file</strong>)
Used internally with the debugger for example.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">execute_find_callers_filename</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>filename of the caller, assumed to be the first non PySimpleGUI file</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Get the text results of a previously executed execute call
Returns a tuple of the strings (stdout, stderr)</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">execute_get_results</span>(subprocess_id, timeout = None)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen)</td>
<td>subprocess_id</td>
<td>a Popen subprocess ID returned from a previous execute call</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(None or float)</td>
<td>timeout</td>
<td>Time in fractions of a second to wait. Returns '','' if timeout. Default of None means wait forever</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Executes a Python file.
The interpreter to use is chosen based on this priority order:
1. interpreter_command paramter
2. global setting "-python command-"
3. the interpreter running running PySimpleGUI</p>
<pre><code class="hljs properties"><span class="hljs-attr">execute_py_file(pyfile,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">parms</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">cwd</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">interpreter_command</span> = <span class="hljs-string">None,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">wait</span> = <span class="hljs-string">False,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">pipe_output</span> = <span class="hljs-string">False,</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">merge_stderr_with_stdout</span> = <span class="hljs-string">True)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>pyfile</td>
<td>the file to run</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>parms</td>
<td>parameters to pass on the command line</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>cwd</td>
<td>the working directory to use</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>interpreter_command</td>
<td>the command used to invoke the Python interpreter</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>wait</td>
<td>the working directory to use</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>pipe_output</td>
<td>If True then output from the subprocess will be piped. You MUST empty the pipe by calling execute_get_results or your subprocess will block until no longer full</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>merge_stderr_with_stdout</td>
<td>If True then output from the subprocess stderr will be merged with stdout. The result is ALL output will be on stdout.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen) or None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>Popen object</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Returns True is the subprocess ID provided is for a process that is still running</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">execute_subprocess_still_running</span>(subprocess_id)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(subprocess.Popen)</td>
<td>subprocess_id</td>
<td>ID previously returned from Exec API calls that indicate this value is returned</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>True if the subproces is running</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<hr>
<h2 id="clipboard-apis">Clipboard APIs</h2>
<p>Note that this clipboard uses tkinter's clipboard. There is a known limitation that your application needs to remain running until you've pasted the contents.  Managed to get around this limitation so that the clipboard stays set after you exit your application, but only have it working for Windows systems.</p>
<p>Gets the clipboard current value.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">clipboard_get</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str)</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>The current value of the clipboard</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Sets the clipboard to a specific value.
IMPORTANT NOTE - Your PySimpleGUI application needs to remain running until you've pasted
your clipboard. This is a tkinter limitation.  A workaround was found for Windows, but you still
need to stay running for Linux systems.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">clipboard_set</span>(new_value)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>(str or bytes)</td>
<td>new_value</td>
<td>value to set the clipboard to. Will be converted to a string</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2 id="misc">Misc</h2>
<p>Fills a window with values provided in a values dictionary { element_key : new_value }</p>
<pre><code class="hljs coffeescript">fill_form_with_values(<span class="hljs-built_in">window</span>, values_dict)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Window</td>
<td>window</td>
<td>The window object to fill</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(Dict[Any, Any])</td>
<td>values_dict</td>
<td>A dictionary with element keys as key and value is values parm for Update call</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Fills a window with values provided in a values dictionary { element_key : new_value }</p>
<pre><code class="hljs coffeescript">FillFormWithValues(<span class="hljs-built_in">window</span>, values_dict)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Window</td>
<td>window</td>
<td>The window object to fill</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(Dict[Any, Any])</td>
<td>values_dict</td>
<td>A dictionary with element keys as key and value is values parm for Update call</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2 id="application-wide-configuration-settings-set_options-etc">Application-wide Configuration / Settings (<code>set_options</code>, etc)</h2>
<p>Sets the icon which will be used any time a window is created if an icon is not provided when the
window is created.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">set_global_icon</span>(icon)
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>bytes or str</td>
<td>icon</td>
<td>Either a Base64 byte string or a filename</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<pre><code class="hljs python">set_options(icon = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    button_color = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    element_size = (<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>),

<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>bytes or str</td>
<td>icon</td>
<td>Can be either a filename or Base64 value. For Windows if filename, it MUST be ICO format. For Linux, must NOT be ICO. Most portable is to use a Base64 of a PNG file. This works universally across all OS's</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str, str) or str</td>
<td>button_color</td>
<td>Color of the button (text, background)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>element_size</td>
<td>element size (width, height) in characters</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>button_element_size</td>
<td>Size of button</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>margins</td>
<td>(left/right, top/bottom) tkinter margins around outsize. Amount of pixels to leave inside the window's frame around the edges before your elements are shown.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int or (int, int),(int,int))</td>
<td>element_padding</td>
<td>Default amount of padding to put around elements in window (left/right, top/bottom) or ((left, right), (top, bottom))</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>auto_size_text</td>
<td>True if the Widget should be shrunk to exactly fit the number of chars to show</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>auto_size_buttons</td>
<td>True if Buttons in this Window should be sized to exactly fit the text on this.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or (str, int[, str]) or None)</td>
<td>font</td>
<td>specifies the font family, size, etc. Tuple or Single string format 'name size styles'. Styles: italic * roman bold normal underline overstrike</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>border_width</td>
<td>width of border around element</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>slider_border_width</td>
<td>Width of the border around sliders</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>slider_relief</td>
<td>Type of relief to use for sliders</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>slider_orientation</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>autoclose_time</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>message_box_line_width</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_border_depth</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_style</td>
<td>You can no longer set a progress bar style. All ttk styles must be the same for the window</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_relief</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_color</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_size</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>'left' or 'right' or 'center'</td>
<td>text_justification</td>
<td>Default text justification for all Text Elements in window</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>background_color</td>
<td>color of background</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>element_background_color</td>
<td>element background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>text_element_background_color</td>
<td>text element background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>input_elements_background_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the background of input elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>input_text_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the text for Input elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>scrollbar_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the slider trough</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>text_color</td>
<td>color of the text</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>element_text_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for Text elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>debug_win_size</td>
<td>window size</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int) or None</td>
<td>window_location</td>
<td>Default location to place windows. Not setting will center windows on the display</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>error_button_color</td>
<td>(Default = (None))</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>tooltip_time</td>
<td>time in milliseconds to wait before showing a tooltip. Default is 400ms</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or Tuple[str, int] or Tuple[str, int, str]</td>
<td>tooltip_font</td>
<td>font to use for all tooltips</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_ttk_buttons</td>
<td>if True will cause all buttons to be ttk buttons</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>ttk_theme</td>
<td>Theme to use with ttk widgets. Choices (on Windows) include - 'default', 'winnative', 'clam', 'alt', 'classic', 'vista', 'xpnative'</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_error_popups</td>
<td>If True then error popups will not be shown if generated internally to PySimpleGUI</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_raise_key_errors</td>
<td>If True then key errors won't be raised (you'll still get popup error)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_key_guessing</td>
<td>If True then key errors won't try and find closest matches for you</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>warn_button_key_duplicates</td>
<td>If True then duplicate Button Keys generate warnings (not recommended as they're expected)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>enable_treeview_869_patch</td>
<td>If True, then will use the treeview color patch for tk 8.6.9</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>enable_mac_notitlebar_patch</td>
<td>If True then Windows with no titlebar use an alternative technique when tkinter version &lt; 8.6.10</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_custom_titlebar</td>
<td>If True then a custom titlebar is used instead of the normal system titlebar</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or None</td>
<td>titlebar_background_color</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or None</td>
<td>titlebar_text_color</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as text color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or (str, int[, str]) or None) or None</td>
<td>titlebar_font</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as title font</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bytes or str</td>
<td>titlebar_icon</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as the icon (file or base64 bytes)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>user_settings_path</td>
<td>default path for user_settings API calls. Expanded with os.path.expanduser so can contain ~ to represent user</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>pysimplegui_settings_path</td>
<td>default path for the global PySimpleGUI user_settings</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>pysimplegui_settings_filename</td>
<td>default filename for the global PySimpleGUI user_settings</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>keep_on_top</td>
<td>If True then all windows will automatically be set to keep_on_top=True</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>dpi_awareness</td>
<td>If True then will turn on DPI awareness (Windows only at the moment)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>float</td>
<td>scaling</td>
<td>Sets the default scaling for all windows including popups, etc.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>disable_modal_windows</td>
<td>If True then all windows, including popups, will not be modal windows (unless they've been set to FORCED using another option)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>force_modal_windows</td>
<td>If True then all windows will be modal (the disable option will be ignored... all windows will be forced to be modal)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>((None, None) or (int, int))</td>
<td>tooltip_offset</td>
<td>Offset to use for tooltips as a tuple. These values will be added to the mouse location when the widget was entered.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_trough_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the trough</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_background_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the background of the arrow buttons at the ends AND the color of the "thumb" (the thing you grab and slide). Switches to arrow color when mouse is over</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_arrow_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the arrow at the ends of the scrollbar (it looks like a button). Switches to background color when mouse is over</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>sbar_width</td>
<td>Scrollbar width in pixels</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>sbar_arrow_width</td>
<td>Scrollbar width of the arrow on the scrollbar. It will potentially impact the overall width of the scrollbar</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_frame_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar Color of frame around scrollbar (available only on some ttk themes)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_relief</td>
<td>Scrollbar relief that will be used for the "thumb" of the scrollbar (the thing you grab that slides). Should be a constant that is defined at starting with "RELIEF_" - RELIEF_RAISED, RELIEF_SUNKEN, RELIEF_FLAT, RELIEF_RIDGE, RELIEF_GROOVE, RELIEF_SOLID</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>float</td>
<td>alpha_channel</td>
<td>Default alpha channel to be used on all windows</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>hide_window_when_creating</td>
<td>If True then alpha will be set to 0 while a window is made and moved to location indicated</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_button_shortcuts</td>
<td>If True then Shortcut Char will be used with Buttons</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="non-pep8-versions_1">Non PEP8 versions</h3>
<p>Sets the icon which will be used any time a window is created if an icon is not provided when the
window is created.</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">SetGlobalIcon</span>(icon)
</code></pre>

<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>bytes or str</td>
<td>icon</td>
<td>Can be either a filename or Base64 value. For Windows if filename, it MUST be ICO format. For Linux, must NOT be ICO. Most portable is to use a Base64 of a PNG file. This works universally across all OS's</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str, str) or str</td>
<td>button_color</td>
<td>Color of the button (text, background)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>element_size</td>
<td>element size (width, height) in characters</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>button_element_size</td>
<td>Size of button</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>margins</td>
<td>(left/right, top/bottom) tkinter margins around outsize. Amount of pixels to leave inside the window's frame around the edges before your elements are shown.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int or (int, int),(int,int))</td>
<td>element_padding</td>
<td>Default amount of padding to put around elements in window (left/right, top/bottom) or ((left, right), (top, bottom))</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>auto_size_text</td>
<td>True if the Widget should be shrunk to exactly fit the number of chars to show</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>auto_size_buttons</td>
<td>True if Buttons in this Window should be sized to exactly fit the text on this.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or (str, int[, str]) or None)</td>
<td>font</td>
<td>specifies the font family, size, etc. Tuple or Single string format 'name size styles'. Styles: italic * roman bold normal underline overstrike</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>border_width</td>
<td>width of border around element</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>slider_border_width</td>
<td>Width of the border around sliders</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>slider_relief</td>
<td>Type of relief to use for sliders</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>slider_orientation</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>autoclose_time</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>message_box_line_width</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_border_depth</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_style</td>
<td>You can no longer set a progress bar style. All ttk styles must be the same for the window</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_relief</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_color</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>progress_meter_size</td>
<td>???</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>'left' or 'right' or 'center'</td>
<td>text_justification</td>
<td>Default text justification for all Text Elements in window</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>background_color</td>
<td>color of background</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>element_background_color</td>
<td>element background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>text_element_background_color</td>
<td>text element background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>input_elements_background_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the background of input elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>input_text_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the text for Input elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>scrollbar_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for the slider trough</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>text_color</td>
<td>color of the text</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>element_text_color</td>
<td>Default color to use for Text elements</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>debug_win_size</td>
<td>window size</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int) or None</td>
<td>window_location</td>
<td>Default location to place windows. Not setting will center windows on the display</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>???</td>
<td>error_button_color</td>
<td>(Default = (None))</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>tooltip_time</td>
<td>time in milliseconds to wait before showing a tooltip. Default is 400ms</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or Tuple[str, int] or Tuple[str, int, str]</td>
<td>tooltip_font</td>
<td>font to use for all tooltips</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_ttk_buttons</td>
<td>if True will cause all buttons to be ttk buttons</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>ttk_theme</td>
<td>Theme to use with ttk widgets. Choices (on Windows) include - 'default', 'winnative', 'clam', 'alt', 'classic', 'vista', 'xpnative'</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_error_popups</td>
<td>If True then error popups will not be shown if generated internally to PySimpleGUI</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_raise_key_errors</td>
<td>If True then key errors won't be raised (you'll still get popup error)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>suppress_key_guessing</td>
<td>If True then key errors won't try and find closest matches for you</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>warn_button_key_duplicates</td>
<td>If True then duplicate Button Keys generate warnings (not recommended as they're expected)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>enable_treeview_869_patch</td>
<td>If True, then will use the treeview color patch for tk 8.6.9</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>enable_mac_notitlebar_patch</td>
<td>If True then Windows with no titlebar use an alternative technique when tkinter version &lt; 8.6.10</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_custom_titlebar</td>
<td>If True then a custom titlebar is used instead of the normal system titlebar</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or None</td>
<td>titlebar_background_color</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as background color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str or None</td>
<td>titlebar_text_color</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as text color</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(str or (str, int[, str]) or None) or None</td>
<td>titlebar_font</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as title font</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bytes or str</td>
<td>titlebar_icon</td>
<td>If custom titlebar indicated by use_custom_titlebar, then use this as the icon (file or base64 bytes)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>user_settings_path</td>
<td>default path for user_settings API calls. Expanded with os.path.expanduser so can contain ~ to represent user</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>pysimplegui_settings_path</td>
<td>default path for the global PySimpleGUI user_settings</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>pysimplegui_settings_filename</td>
<td>default filename for the global PySimpleGUI user_settings</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>keep_on_top</td>
<td>If True then all windows will automatically be set to keep_on_top=True</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>dpi_awareness</td>
<td>If True then will turn on DPI awareness (Windows only at the moment)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>float</td>
<td>scaling</td>
<td>Sets the default scaling for all windows including popups, etc.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>disable_modal_windows</td>
<td>If True then all windows, including popups, will not be modal windows (unless they've been set to FORCED using another option)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>force_modal_windows</td>
<td>If True then all windows will be modal (the disable option will be ignored... all windows will be forced to be modal)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>((None, None) or (int, int))</td>
<td>tooltip_offset</td>
<td>Offset to use for tooltips as a tuple. These values will be added to the mouse location when the widget was entered.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_trough_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the trough</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_background_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the background of the arrow buttons at the ends AND the color of the "thumb" (the thing you grab and slide). Switches to arrow color when mouse is over</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_arrow_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar color of the arrow at the ends of the scrollbar (it looks like a button). Switches to background color when mouse is over</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>sbar_width</td>
<td>Scrollbar width in pixels</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>sbar_arrow_width</td>
<td>Scrollbar width of the arrow on the scrollbar. It will potentially impact the overall width of the scrollbar</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_frame_color</td>
<td>Scrollbar Color of frame around scrollbar (available only on some ttk themes)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>sbar_relief</td>
<td>Scrollbar relief that will be used for the "thumb" of the scrollbar (the thing you grab that slides). Should be a constant that is defined at starting with "RELIEF_" - RELIEF_RAISED, RELIEF_SUNKEN, RELIEF_FLAT, RELIEF_RIDGE, RELIEF_GROOVE, RELIEF_SOLID</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>float</td>
<td>alpha_channel</td>
<td>Default alpha channel to be used on all windows</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>hide_window_when_creating</td>
<td>If True then alpha will be set to 0 while a window is made and moved to location indicated</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>use_button_shortcuts</td>
<td>If True then Shortcut Char will be used with Buttons</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2 id="old-themes-look-and-feel-replaced-by-theme">Old Themes (Look and Feel) - Replaced by theme()</h2>
<p>You should NOT use these calls.  They are here for your reference should you run into them in existing code.</p>
<p>Change the "color scheme" of all future PySimpleGUI Windows.
The scheme are string names that specify a group of colors. Background colors, text colors, button colors.
There are 13 different color settings that are changed at one time using a single call to ChangeLookAndFeel
The look and feel table itself has these indexes into the dictionary LOOK_AND_FEEL_TABLE.
The original list was (prior to a major rework and renaming)... these names still work...
In Nov 2019 a new Theme Formula was devised to make choosing a theme easier:
The "Formula" is:
["Dark" or "Light"] Color Number
Colors can be Blue Brown Grey Green Purple Red Teal Yellow Black
The number will vary for each pair. There are more DarkGrey entries than there are LightYellow for example.
Default = The default settings (only button color is different than system default)
Default1 = The full system default including the button (everything's gray... how sad... don't be all gray... please....)</p>
<pre><code class="hljs yaml"><span class="hljs-string">ChangeLookAndFeel(index,</span> <span class="hljs-string">force</span> <span class="hljs-string">=</span> <span class="hljs-literal">False</span><span class="hljs-string">)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>index</td>
<td>the name of the index into the Look and Feel table (does not have to be exact, can be "fuzzy")</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>force</td>
<td>no longer used</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Get a list of the valid values to pass into your call to change_look_and_feel</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">ListOfLookAndFeelValues</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>List[str]</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>list of valid string values</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Displays a "Quick Reference Window" showing all of the different Look and Feel settings that are available.
They are sorted alphabetically.  The legacy color names are mixed in, but otherwise they are sorted into Dark and Light halves</p>
<pre><code class="hljs python">preview_all_look_and_feel_themes(columns = <span class="hljs-number">12</span>,
    scrollable = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>,
    scroll_area_size = (<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>),
    search_string = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>,
    location = (<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>))
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>columns</td>
<td>The number of themes to display per row</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>scrollable</td>
<td>If True then scrollbars will be added</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>scroll_area_size</td>
<td>Size of the scrollable area (The Column Element used to make scrollable)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>search_string</td>
<td>If specified then only themes containing this string will be shown</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>(int, int)</td>
<td>location</td>
<td>Location on the screen to place the window. Defaults to the center like all windows</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Get a list of the valid values to pass into your call to change_look_and_feel</p>
<pre><code class="hljs less"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">list_of_look_and_feel_values</span>()
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>List[str]</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>list of valid string values</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Change the "color scheme" of all future PySimpleGUI Windows.
The scheme are string names that specify a group of colors. Background colors, text colors, button colors.
There are 13 different color settings that are changed at one time using a single call to ChangeLookAndFeel
The look and feel table itself has these indexes into the dictionary LOOK_AND_FEEL_TABLE.
The original list was (prior to a major rework and renaming)... these names still work...
In Nov 2019 a new Theme Formula was devised to make choosing a theme easier:
The "Formula" is:
["Dark" or "Light"] Color Number
Colors can be Blue Brown Grey Green Purple Red Teal Yellow Black
The number will vary for each pair. There are more DarkGrey entries than there are LightYellow for example.
Default = The default settings (only button color is different than system default)
Default1 = The full system default including the button (everything's gray... how sad... don't be all gray... please....)</p>
<pre><code class="hljs yaml"><span class="hljs-string">change_look_and_feel(index,</span> <span class="hljs-string">force</span> <span class="hljs-string">=</span> <span class="hljs-literal">False</span><span class="hljs-string">)</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Parameter Descriptions:</p>
<table class="table table-striped table-hover">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>str</td>
<td>index</td>
<td>the name of the index into the Look and Feel table (does not have to be exact, can be "fuzzy")</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>bool</td>
<td>force</td>
<td>no longer used</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>None</td>
<td><strong>RETURN</strong></td>
<td>None</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
